title-group.article-title: Mollusks as indicators of historical changes in an estuarine-lagoonal system (Cananéia-Iguape, SE Brazil)

article-meta.aff: 1Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
2Instituto Oceanográfico da Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil

author-notes.corresp: Sergio Martínez, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Iguá 4225, 11400 Montevideo, Uruguay. Email: smart@fcien.edu.uy; lburone@gmail.com

abstract.p: Mollusks recovered from three cores taken from the Cananéia-Iguape estuarine-lagoonal system (São Paulo State, Brazil) were studied. The sampled sediments cover a period beginning approximately two centuries ago and end at the present, including a period when the system suffered significant changes of anthropogenic origin – that is, the construction of an artificial channel connecting the lagoon with a nearby river and with the resulting input of fresh water and contaminants generated from mining activity upstream. The mollusk composition reflects these changes. The more abrupt changes in this composition coincide with the opening of the Valo Grande artificial channel in 1852. Another significant but minor change event was verified for around 1977± one year in areas that were not previously affected, perhaps showing the effect of the closing and reopening of the channel.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lagoon and estuary environments are highly susceptible to the influence of human activity. In addition to naturally intrusive forces such as tides, currents, and wind, anthropogenic influences can greatly alter the variability of salinity in these areas. Upstream dams constructed for hydroelectric power plants and for alleviating shoaling problems have altered freshwater discharge patterns and salinity regimes. Increased amounts of impervious surface may alter hydrodynamic processes and add to salinity variability (Lerberg, 1997; Lerberg et al., 2000). Furthermore, extractive and industrial activities have magnified this influence over the last few centuries by dumping large amounts of pollutants into the water. Waste from industrial production and the extraction of raw material has been frequently and routinely discarded in these environments. A decrease in biodiversity is the most common outcome of these actions (Clarke and Warwick, 1994).

Different proxies have been used to study the impact of human influence in the sedimentary record (e.g. Cearreta et al., 2000, 2002; Corredeira et al., 2008; Willis and Bhagwat, 2010); among the biological indicators found in marine or estuarine sediments, foraminifers have been the most popular. However, other biological groups, such as mollusks, can be used as anthropogenic influence indicators in the sedimentary record (and not just as accumulators of substances, such as heavy metals). Faunal changes have been registered in recent times, and the comparison between live–dead assemblages has been used as a proxy for environmental changes (e.g. Edelman-Furstenberg and Faershtein, 2010; Ferguson, 2008; Kidwell, 2007, 2008).

In fact, Mollusca are a major biological group with great preservation potential that is sensitive to changes in environmental conditions. Mollusks have been widely used in paleoecological reconstructions, providing information on sediment properties, oxygen levels, and water energy, among other ecological characteristics (Clarke and Warwick, 1994; Edelman-Furstenberg, 2008; Levin et al., 2000; Rhoads and Boyer, 1982; Rhoads and Morse, 1971). The distribution of mollusks in shallow waters is especially important because the anthropogenic influence is more intense in these areas.

Despite the antecedents, there are few long-term variation studies about mollusks in a given locality. Mendes et al. (2006) briefly discuss faunal differences in Guanabara Bay (Brazil) using surveys completed 50 years ago. Van der Meij et al. (2009) studied collections that were up to 70 years old, but these were linked to a coral reef complex. Capasso et al. (2010) investigated disturbances caused by human fishing in the English Channel during the last 100 years utilizing data from studies performed 112 years ago. Edgar and Samson (2004) registered the diversity of mollusks along core samples representing 120 years in Tasmania, linking its decline with fisheries. Kidwell (2007, 2008) and Kowalewski et al. (2000) studied dead mollusk assemblages in estuaries, lagoons and open shelves, concluding that their composition and diversity can be used to monitor natural and anthropogenic disturbances.

The objective of the present research was to study faunal changes through a continuous sedimentary record in the Cananéia-Iguape estuarine-lagoonal complex, an area that has suffered the consequences of the opening of an artificial freshwater channel and the resulting decrease in salinity in the system. Although we consider dead assemblages, and some taphonomic inertia can be expected (the death assemblage can be compositionally lagged behind strong recent changes in the community; Kidwell, 2007, 2008), this type of approach may provide a reasonable picture of the pre-impact communities (Dietl and Flessa, 2011; Kidwell, 2007, 2008).

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: The Ribeira River forms a large drainage basin on the south–southeast Brazilian coast with an area of approximately 25,000 km2. River discharge varies from approximately 300 m3/s to more than 1200 m3/s in the lower course due to the influence of the subtropical humid climate. The Cananéia-Iguape estuarine-lagoonal system is located near the Ribeira basin and is composed of a series of lagoonal channels that represent the drowning of the paleo-river channels developed after the transgressive phase of Isotope Stage 5e, locally named the Cananéia Transgression (120,000 years BP; Martin and Suguio, 1979; Petri and Suguio, 1973; Suguio and Barcelos, 1978; Figure 1) .

According to Köppen classification, the climate shows characteristics of being humid tropical, varying from humid tropical without a dry season to humid tropical with a cool summer. There is a rainy season from November to February (summer), and annual rainfall average is approximately 2200 mm/yr. Annual average temperatures are between 16°C and 19°C, but extreme temperatures of 0ºC and 35ºC have occasionally been recorded. Salt marshes and mangroves are found at the margins of the mixohaline bodies of water, and vegetation typical of Atlantic Brazilian forests is found in the higher areas.

sec.title: The Valo Grande channel
sec.p: Mining activities in the upper part of the Ribeira River began in the 17th century. From that time through the first half of the 20th century, gold and silver were the metals most commonly extracted; lead was more commonly extracted from 1945 to 1995. Agricultural products, mainly rice, have also been important to this region; these were exported through the Porto Grande (Iguape City), which is situated in the lagoonal system. To shorten the transportation time of rice from the interior to Porto Grande, a 4 km-long artificial channel was excavated that connects the harbour with the Ribeira River. In other words, the river became directly connected with the lagoonal system by an artificial channel. The channel (initially named Valo do Rocio and now called Valo Grande), was opened in 1852 (GEOBRÁS, 1966); at this time, approximately 60% of the river flow was transferred to the lagoonal system. This drastic change led to an abrupt decrease in salinity, modifications in the erosional and depositional processes, contamination by heavy metals and a reduction of cultivated and inhabitable areas (Becegato, 2007; Becegato and Suguio, 2007; Besnard, 1950; Eysink et al., 1988; Moraes et al., 2004; Teles, 1997; Tessler and Mahiques, 1998; Tomassi, 1984; Young, 1903). The channel was originally 4.4 m wide and 2 m deep. Its dimensions, however, increased naturally over a short span of time; currently it is approximately 250 m wide and up to 7 m deep. A dam of stones and sand was constructed in 1978 to close the channel, but this dam was destroyed in 1983 after massive flooding of the Ribeira River.

Mahiques et al. (2009, 2012) dated cores from the lagoonal system using 210Pb estimation of the sedimentation rate and traced the changes in the heavy metal and Foraminifera content over time. They were even able to show the clear impact of the opening of the Valo Grande channel in one of the cores.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: The three studied cores were collected along the main channel of the lagoonal system (Figure 1) utilizing a Rossfelder VT-1 vibracorer. Core CAN5 was previously studied by Mahiques et al. (2009) and, along with it, cores CAN2 and CAN7 were analysed by Mahiques et al. (2012). The distance from the Valo Grande channel was taken into consideration to ensure that different conditions were recorded. Core CAN2 was situated near the opening of the Valo Grande channel (24º42.447′S 47º32.787′W, 144 cm in length); core CAN7 was located farther from it (24º48.895′S, 47º41.612′, 127 cm in length); and core CAN5 (24º45.245′S – 47º37.370′W, 200 cm in length) between them.

The cores were opened, described, and sampled continuously at 2cm intervals. To avoid contamination along the core, only the internal area of the recovered sediment was used for analysis. Sedimentation rates were determined via gamma spectrometry by means of the 210PB photo-peak of 47 keV using a low background Ge detector (EGandG Ortec, model GMX 25190P), as described in Figueira et al. (2007). Details of the procedure can be consulted in Mahiques et al. (2012). Grain size analyses were performed on decarbonated samples using a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 Laser Analyser.

The presence or absence of mollusks was checked every 2 cm. Their abundance was not taken into account because the ratio between typical shell size and the diameter of the core is high. Similarity and dissimilarity among the content of mollusks of the samples was evaluated using both the Dice association coefficient and the Raup and Crick (1979) index. The Dice association coefficient is defined by the following equation: Dice coefficient = 2a/(2a + b + c), where a is the number of taxa shared by the samples and b and c are the taxa present in one sample and absent in the other. The Raup and Crick index is defined as the probability that kexp will be less than or equal to kobs, where kexp is the theoretically possible values of k generated by Monte Carlo simulations, kobs is the number of taxa actually shared by assemblages, and k is the number of taxa common to both assemblages. Although the Dice coefficient provides minimum distortion in binary data (Archer and Maples, 1987; Maples and Archer, 1988), the Raup and Crick index was also calculated because it uses a randomized Monte Carlo procedure. Non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS, only Dice index), Q-mode (unweighted pair group method with arithmetic mean [UPGMA]) cluster analysis and K-means clustering were performed. The computer program used for each analysis was PAST, v. 2.10 (Hammer et al., 2001).

sec.title: Grain size characteristics and sedimentation rates
sec.p: Sediment in CAN2 is composed by a high percentage of very fine sand with a mean diameter approximately 4ф. The average sedimentation rate of the core, obtained by 210Pb dating, was found to be 0.72±0.01 cm/yr.

CAN5 has a basal zone composed mostly of sand with less than 5% as calcium carbonate and organic matter content. At 130 cm, an abrupt change occurs, where a muddy sedimentation is found, beginning with more than 10% organic content and even higher calcium carbonate content. At 50 cm there is another change, but it is only registered by magnetic susceptibility. CAN07 is composed almost exclusively of very fine sand. The distribution of grain size along the cores is shown in Figure 2. A more detailed description of the core CAN5 can be obtained in Mahiques et al. (2009).

caption.p: Mean grain size in each studied core. Modified from Alves (2009).

sec.p: Calendar ages of the samples were taken from Alves (2009) and Mahiques et al. (2009, 2012) and were calculated using 210Pb estimations of the sedimentation rate. CAN2 comprises the years between ad 1865± 9 and ad 2005± 0; CAN5 comprises the years between ad 1725± 9 and 2006± 0; and CAN7 comprises the years between ad 1820± 9 and 2004± 0.

sec.title: Mollusk species living today in the Cananéia-Iguape lagoonal system
sec.p: Present-day mollusks (Appendix 1) have invariably been collected in a consistent pattern around Cananéia Island; that is, not in the surroundings of the Valo Grande channel, where the influence of the channelized water is best recorded (v.gr. salinity; see Coimbra et al., 2007). These data may be used therefore as a control sample for comparison with the mollusks present in the cores before and after the opening of the artificial channel. Data from Morretes (1954), Gerlach (1958), Tomassi (1970), Marini (1988), Flynn et al. (1998), Jorcin (1999), de Oliveira et al. (2006), Yamagata et al. (2007), and Pereira et al. (2003) were considered in this study. Unfortunately, in some papers there are neither descriptions nor illustrations of the taxa, and some identifications at the specific level are doubtful. Furthermore, in some of these papers, there is no sign of a repository for the specimens. Therefore some specimens will be referred to only at the genus level in order to reasonably minimize errors. However, these taxonomic doubts do not affect the analysis because the generic identification is enough for these purposes, as shown below. The nomenclature has been updated according to Rosenberg (2009). Taxonomy can be consulted in Appendix 3.

sec.title: Mollusks recovered in the cores
sec.p: A summary of present and recovered species may be found in Appendix 1. A list of mollusks present in the cores every 2 cm is provided in Appendices 2.1 (CAN2), 2.2 (CAN5) and 2.3 (CAN7). Some frequently found taxa are illustrated in Figure 3. Richness is illustrated in Figure 4. Taxonomy can be consulted in Appendix 3.

caption.p: 1. Heleobia cf. australis, CAN5/130–132 cm; 2. Chione cancellata, external view, CAN5/152–154 cm; 3. idem, internal view; 4. Anomalocardia brasiliana, outer view, CAN7/38–40 cm; 5. idem, CAN7/38–40 cm, internal view; 6. Corbula cymella, CAN5/148–148 cm, external view; 7. Erodona mactroides, CAN7/32–34 cm; and 8. idem, CAN7/86–88 cm.
Molluscan richness along the cores. Triangles indicate the presence of Erodona mactroides. The estimated year for the base of each core and some key dates are also indicated (see text).

sec.p:
The main results regarding mollusk fauna for each core are as follows:
CAN2. Mollusks are found from 64–66 cm (year 1941+/− 4) to 32–34 cm (year 1975+/− 2) in CAN2. Erodona mactroides, Heleobia cf. australis, and debris from Mytilidae were recorded. Erodona mactroides is present over almost all this range. Heleobia cf. australis is also present in most samples, but it is not as constant as E. mactroides. This core shows low diversity with no more than two species found together (sometimes with indeterminate debris).
CAN5. Fifteen species of mollusks are present from 184 to186 cm (year 1750+/− 8) in CAN5. Mollusks appear again from 164 to 166 cm (year 1786+/− 7) and from 158 to 160 cm (year 1797+/− 7) to 122–124 cm (year 1866+/− 4). From 130 cm (year 1852+/− 4) to 122 cm (year 1863+/− 1) there is only indeterminate debris, possibly Mytilidae, and Heleobia cf. australis. The maximum richness is registered between 146 to 158 cm (year 1801+/− 6 to year 1823+/− 6), up to seven taxa at 154 to 156 cm (year 1805+/− 6). Heleobia cf. australis and Chione cancellata were the most represented species along the core CAN7. A total of 11 taxa are recorded at CAN7. Shells appear at 90 to 92 cm (year 1870+/− 7) and disappear at 6 to 8 cm (year 1998+/− 0). The fauna is fairly constant in richness, with a peak of six species at 22 to 24 cm (year 1974+/− 2). From 20 cm (year 1977+/− 1) to the top, there are only shells of Erodona mactroides and Heleobia cf. australis, species that occur throughout most of the core. With the exception of Anomalocardia brasiliana, the other taxa occur only sporadically along the core. There is abundant debris in this core.

There are some species that live in the lagoonal system today that were not recorded in the cores, including Stramonita mariae, Littoraria angulifera, Neritina virginea, Tagelus sp., Thracia? sp., Diplodonta sp., Divalinga quadrisulcata, undetermined Olividae, Crepidula sp., Ostrea sp., Modiolus carvalhoi, Turbonilla nivea, Lucina sp., Nassarius vibex, and Sphenia fragilis. This could be a sampling artefact. On the other hand, there are other species in the core samples that are not registered in the current living system, including Boonea sp., Urosalpinx sp., Semele sp., Raeta? sp., Cyrtopleura? sp., Caryocorbula caribaea, Caryocorbula cymella, and chitons. We could not find a unifying clear explanation for the absence of these species in the present environments.

sec.title: Comments on the taxonomy and ecology of the recovered mollusks
Heleobia cf. australis (Figure 3.1)
sec.p: Material from this mollusk has been identified only at the genus level because the anatomy of the specimens is unknown (although it is known in the local literature as Heleobia australis) and shell shape alone is not enough to discriminate among species within the genus (De Francesco, 2007). Estuarine species of Heleobia (including H. australis) live in the coastal lagoons of Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina. They also live along the coast of the Rio de la Plata from the intertidal to the subtidal zones in every type of substrate, but primarily in muddy ones (Scarabino et al., 2006, and references). Positive interactions between H. australis and the smooth cord grass Spartina alterniflora have been found (Canepuccia et al., 2007). H. cf. australis is a second-order opportunistic species that is resistant to contamination (Muniz et al., 2005, 2011; Brugnoli et al., 2007). This species is present today in the areas around Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Pyramidellidae
sec.p: Pyramidellids are ectoparasites of other invertebrates. In particular, Boonea is considered a generalist, feeding on a wide spectrum of mollusks. Because the potential hosts are either marine (v.gr. Crepidula) or estuarine (v.gr. Crassostrea), the same habitats can be considered for the genus (Nalesso et al., 2005; Robertson and Mau-Lastovicka, 1979). Pyramidellids are not present today at the surroundings of Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Urosalpinx sp
sec.p: Species of this genus are predators of mollusks and other invertebrates. They live in rocks or consolidated sediment of the subtidal to infralittoral zones. Urosalpinx spp. flourish in marine environments but tolerate estuaries (Carranza, et al., 2006; Federighi, 1931; Franz, 1971; Hill et al., 2005; Manzi, 1970; Scarabino, Zaffaroni). The species of this genus are not present today near Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Acteocina sp
sec.p: This species is called Acteocina canaliculata in the local literature, but it is more likely Acteocina candei, according to shell characteristics. At present, a generic identification is sufficient. Acteocina spp. live in the sea and in lagoons (eury- and polyhaline) in a variety of substrates (Amstrong, 1987; Carranza, et al., 2006; Llansó et al., 2002; Mikkelsen et al., 1995; Scarabino, Zaffaroni). It is present today in the areas around Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Mytilidae
sec.p: Among the present fauna, two species of Mytella (M. guyanensis and M. falcata) and Mytilus sp. are mentioned; however, only debris has been found, rendering genus level identification impossible. Mytella guyanensis and M. falcata (euryhaline species) live attached to diverse objects, such as the base of mangrove prop-roots, or superficially buried in the muddy substrate of lagoons and intertidal flats (Bacon, 1975; Nalesso et al., 2005). Species of Mytilus prefer the intertidal and subtidal zones where they attach to a great variety of substrata in the open sea, or brackish estuaries with water movement (Bayne, 1976; Scarabino et al., 2006); these species may be found today near Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Raeta sp
sec.p: Species of this genus live in shallow sandy or sandy-muddy protected coasts (Scarabino et al., 2006) and they are not present today in areas near Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Tellina spp
sec.p: These euryhaline species live in sandy and sandy-muddy substrates of the subtidal zone of the outermost estuaries and bays (Amaral et al., 2006) and are present nowadays in areas near Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Macoma sp
sec.p: Species of this genus are mostly euryhaline and subtidal. They live in muddy to sandy substrates (Eisma et al., 1976; Olafsson, 1989) and are present nowadays around Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Semele sp
sec.p: The species of Semele are marine infaunal burrowers in sandy substrates of the intertidal and subtidal zones (Urban and Campos, 1994) and they are not present today near Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Chione cancellata (Figures 3.2–3.3)
sec.p: This euryhaline species is found in sandy and muddy-sandy substrates of the intertidal and the subtidal zones (Amaral et al., 2006; Boehs et al., 2004; Moore and Lopez, 1969; Rios, 2009; Rooparine and Vermeij, 2000). This species is present nowadays in areas near Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Anomalocardia brasiliana (Figures 3.4–3.5)
sec.p: This euryhaline species is found in the outermost estuaries and bays in muddy substrates of the intertidal zone (Amaral et al., 2006; Boehs et al., 2004; Nalesso et al., 2005). It is sensitive to pollution (Muniz et al., 2005) and it is present nowadays in areas near Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Caryocorbula cymella (Figure 3.6) and C. caribaea
sec.p: These euryhaline species live in the fine sediments of the subtidal zone (Mendes et al., 2006; Rios, 2009; Soares-Gomes and Fernandes, 2005) and they are not present today around Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Erodona mactroides (Figures 3.7–3.8)
sec.p: A stricto sensu estuarine species, it lives in muddy or muddy-sandy substrates, in the intertidal and subtidal zones (Carcelles, 1941; Cortelezzi et al., 2007; da Costa, 1971; Rios, 2009, among others). It tolerates some degree of pollution (Brugnoli et al., 2007; Muniz et al., 2005, 2011) and is nowadays around Cananéia Island.

sec.title: Multivariate analyses
sec.p: As seen in Figures 5 and 6 (cluster and NMDS analysis), when comparing the mollusks found in CAN5 below 130 cm (CAN5B) with those from the upper part (CAN5A), and when comparing CAN5B with those from the other cores and with the present fauna, CAN5B groups with CAN7 (the core furthest from the mouth of the Valo Grande channel). On the other hand, CAN5A is more similar to CAN2 (the core nearest to the mouth of the Valo Grande channel) than to any other. The living mollusk fauna is somewhat related to the CAN5B-CAN7 group (Dice index), or is placed apart from the cores (Raup and Crick index). When performing K-means clustering for the maximum possible groups (i.e. four), the only pair remaining is CAN5B-CAN7, being the topology ([CAN5A] [Today] [CAN7-CAN5B] [CAN2]). When selecting for two groups in K-means clustering, the species living today form one group, while those recovered from the cores form another group, being the topology ([Today] [CAN2-CAN5-CAN7]).

caption.p: Cluster analysis (Q Mode). 1. cores and present fauna, Dice index; 2. cores and present fauna, Raup and Crick index; 3. cores and present fauna, core CAN5 split into an upper part (CAN5A) and a lower one (CAN5B), Dice index; 4. cores and present fauna, core CAN5 splitted in an upper part (CAN5A) and a lower one (CAN5B), Raup and Crick index.
NMDS with a superimposed minimum spanning tree. 1. cores and present fauna, Dice index; 2. cores and present fauna, core CAN5 split into an upper part (CAN5A) and a lower one (CAN5B), Dice index.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Twenty-two living species of mollusks were recognized in the Iguape-Cananéia lagoonal system; 17 of these were recovered in the cores, representing approximately 77% of the living species. Nine other taxa from the cores (i.e. approximately half of them) are not known to occur at present in the lagoon. Although the distribution of species in lagoons can be heterogeneous (Benedetti-Cecchi et al., 2001; Hernández-Arana and Ameneyro-Angeles, 2011), the Cananéia-Iguape lagoonal system has been studied for decades; therefore it is not likely that nine mollusk species (those known from the cores) are being overlooked due to inappropriate sampling. In other lagoons, the presence in the bottom of fossils reworked from fossil assemblages has been proven (De Francesco and Hassan, 2006), but this does not seem to be the case in the study area. Although there are abundant Upper Pleistocene sediments deposited in the coastal plains in the area (Angulo and Lessa, 1997; Suguio and Barcelos, 1978; Suguio et al., 2003), no fossil mollusks have been found. It seems clear that mollusk composition has changed along the years.

The CAN2 core, the closest core to the Valo Grande channel, contains a sedimentary record deposited after the opening of the channel, and the presence of only Erodona mactroides and H. cf. australis clearly reflects the impact of freshwater. Additionally, both species have been shown to be tolerant to pollution (Brugnoli et al., 2007; Muniz et al., 2005, 2011), as was discussed earlier.

Mollusks from the CAN5 core show the effects of the opening of the Valo Grande channel. At 130 cm (year 1852+/− 4), there is a clear change. Before this date, 12 species from marine or euryhaline origins are registered, including one that is characteristic of brackish waters (Heleobia cf. australis) and another one that can be of one or another category, depending on which species is concerned (Mytilidae indet.). From 130 m to the top, there is only indeterminate debris (Mytilidae?) and a few centimetres with Heleobia cf. australis. This change is notably related to the opening of the Valo Grande channel in 1852, the same year as the most probable age of the 130 cm sample. The great decrease in salinity (and possibly the beginning of pollution) caused the disappearance of the marine and euryhaline species, leaving only a very tolerant species, Heleobia cf. australis, after 1852. As mentioned earlier, this gastropod can survive in very unfavourable conditions, in very variable environments (such as the Rio de la Plata), and in polluted environments (such as Montevideo Harbour; Muniz et al., 2005, 2011; Scarabino et al., 2006). It is important to note the absence of Erodona mactroides along the core. Because it is a strictly brackish water species, its absence could indicate higher saline conditions before the Valo Grande channel opening. Moreover, this species is present in CAN7, the farthest core from the channel that shows fauna after the opening of the channel.

Shells are found exclusively in samples corresponding to post-opening dates in CAN7, the farthest core from the mouth of the Valo Grande channel, although this core also records the sedimentation prior to the opening of the artificial channel. CAN7 contains marine and marine euryhaline species, except for the almost exclusive presence of Heleobia cf. australis and Erodona mactroides in the last 20 cm (1977+/− 1 to 2004+/− 1). As was mentioned in the introduction, a dam of stones and sand was constructed in 1978 to close the channel, but this dam was destroyed in 1983 after massive flooding of the Ribeira River, and perhaps only these species have been able to cope with these rapid changes. Perhaps this fact reflects that fresh water and contaminants from the Valo Grande channel has extended its influence even further during recent years.

Both mollusks from CAN7 and CAN2 reflect conditions after the opening of the Valo Grande channel, but their faunistic content is very different. The first core was most likely less affected by the opening of the channel, while the second seems to have been more affected by its opening. This spatial compositional difference is recorded as a change through time in the core that comprises pre- and post-channel opening sedimentation (CAN5). The change in the mollusk fauna of CAN5 dovetails with previous studies concerning sedimentology and microfossils (Mahiques et al., 2009). These authors showed that, at the same key level of 130 cm, the sediments become finer, contain higher organic matter values, and show the appearance of thecamoebians; calcareous foraminifers were missing earlier, below 134 cm.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The general composition of the mollusk fauna of the Cananéia-Iguape estuarine-lagoonal system has changed over the last two centuries. The more abrupt change coincides with the opening of the Valo Grande artificial channel in 1852, which introduced large amounts of fresh and contaminated water into the system. Another change occurred around 1977+/− 1 year in areas that were not previously affected, probably as the consequence of the closing and second opening of the channel between 1978 and 1983. The records of continuous dead mollusk assemblages postulate as very promising indicators of changing environments and pollution due to human activities.

ack.p: Students of the course ‘Moluscos como indicadores paleoambientales y paleoclimáticos’ (Programa de Pós-Graduação em Oceanografia Química e Geológica (USP) collaborated with the picking. Alejandra Rojas helped with mollusk identification. Anita Aisenberg improved the language. Patricia Kelley and an anonymous reviewer made valuable suggestions.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
